channel.title: What is deobbers?
channel.description: what is deobbers? couldnt find anything on google

item.title: What is deobbers?
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

Correct, they only reason we rename is so that other programs viewing the source such as “javac” don’t get confused by ambiguous names.

Edit: this topic saddens me as I remember the days I used to chat with saevion and thought he was a noob because of the issues he was having renaming with BCEL. (The real problem was that he didn’t understand the class file format per-say, and he had some caching issues with his “ID” classes.)

Read full topic

item.title: What is deobbers?
item.dc:creator: @popcorn89 popcorn89
item.description:
@popcorn89 wrote:

yakman:

what we do here is to remove this obfuscation, and make the names of things have more sence, now they are called method34() and method645()

That’s hardly deobfuscation, the name method645 still doesn’t give you any idea what the method does.

Read full topic

item.title: What is deobbers?
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

They also tack on obfuscater method args, and make incredibly inaccurate shifts. Not to mention they replace system classes with home brew classes so that the unsigned applet can use the same engine.

Read full topic

item.title: What is deobbers?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

It’s not just names, they also fuck around with flow and suchlike that makes the code uncompilable when it’s deobbed.

Read full topic

item.title: What is deobbers?
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

note: the word ‘deobber’ and ‘deobfuscator’ mean the same thing

you know methods in java, normally they have nice meaningful names like sendPacket() or drawHealthBar()

but jagex change the names so they make no sence, they end up like d764fg45() and ggfh35234(), this is called obfuscation

what we do here is to remove this obfuscation, and make the names of things have more sence, now they are called method34() and method645()

heres an example
Before Obfuscation

public void drawHealthBar() { }

After Obfuscation

public void d45645() { }

After Deobfuscation

public void method453() { }

please note: in the rs2 client its not as simple as drawHealthbar

Read full topic

item.title: What is deobbers?
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Obfuscate, in general, means to make unclear or to ‘obscure’.

Basically, deobfuscating creates readable code, as Mopman said. It makes the beginning stages of a bot/updating system possible. (Well, to me, since I can’t read bytecode fluently, it helps a great deal at finding objects I need).

Read full topic

item.title: What is deobbers?
item.dc:creator: @nicodk nicodk
item.description:
@nicodk wrote:

well what do it then do?

Read full topic

item.title: What is deobbers?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Obfuscation, in the Java sense of the word, means to mess around with a class after is has been compiled so that it cannot be decompiled (or decompiling it results in invalid code). Jagex do this with the Runescape client, so that we can’t mess around with it. However, a number of people have written deobfuscators to undo this classfuckery.

However, deobfuscating the client is no longer as useful as it once was, because running one without heavy modification to certain traps (which nobody has attempted yet? as far as I know…) will result in a ban. They are still a handy tool for learning more about how everything works.

Read full topic
